text: Sure.
speaker: MR. DOBSON

text: -  -  - EXAMINATION
Hi.  My name is Kathleen Eager.  This is a deposition.  Have you ever been deposed before?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: (No response.)
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you ever been in a deposition before?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This is just my opportunity to ask you questions regarding this accident.  There's just a few things to remember about a deposition that are different than the course of a normal conversation. Oftentimes in normal conversations we tend to answer questions by making hand gestures or nodding our head or saying mm-hmm.  In a deposition we have a court reporter, so everything you say has to be audible so she can record it.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Also, during the course of normal conversation sometimes we tend to anticipate the end of a question and we start to answer before the other person is finished.  Once again, because we have a court reporter, she has to record everything we say, so we both can't be speaking at once.  So just try to wait until I'm finished before you answer the question.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: All right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The most important thing to remember is to tell the truth.  If you don't remember something, simply say "I don't remember."  I don't want you to have to guess.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If at any point you need me to repeat a question, or if I'm speaking too fast, which I sometimes do, just ask me and we can do so.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I don't anticipate this taking too long.  I think the setup probably will have taken longer than this actual deposition, but if at any point you need to stop and take a break or speak to your attorney, just let me know and we can do so.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We'll start with something simple.  What's your name?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Preston Moragne.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Your date of birth?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: And your present address?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: 421 Springton Way.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who do you presently reside with?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: My wife and children.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is your wife's name?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Nina.  Same last name.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how many children reside with you?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Well, I have one at home and then one at college -- two at college.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the age of the child at home?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: How long have you lived at that residence?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: About 14 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So, it's safe to say you lived there at the time of the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at the time of the accident were you living with your wife and children as well?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't you tell me a little bit about your educational history.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I have a bachelor's degree from Millersville University.  And I'm a private pilot, certified private pilot.

text: What high school did you graduate from?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Abraham Lincoln High School in Philadelphia.

text: And you said you have a private pilot certification?  Is that what you said?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any other schooling or certifications?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I'm a certified scuba diver.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: That's about it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you presently employed?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where at?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Lancaster Early Education Center.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long have you been employed there?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: There, about -- going on like three weeks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Because I volunteer there also, so...
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What are your job duties there?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I do the marketing for them.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that full-time?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Monday through Friday?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: 40 hours a week?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you paid hourly or by salary?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: It is salary.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know what that is by chance?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: It's like 22.50.  22.50 an hour is what it boils out to be.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where did you work prior to that?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Prior to that, I also own my own company which I do marketing for.  It's a marketing company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is that company's name?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Karman Line Marketing, with a "K".
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you have that company?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Five years, at least.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that where you were working at the time of the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of job duties do you do at your company?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I did digital marketing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just to verify, there is no wage loss or loss of earning capacity claim; correct?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Right.
speaker: MR. DOBSON

text: Let's talk about the date of the accident. Do you remember the date?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: The date itself?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I just remember it was in May.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would May 10th, 2016 sound correct?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I would say so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the time?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: It was in the afternoon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how about the weather conditions that day?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Clear.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about the roadway?  Was it wet; was it dry, if you can recall?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Dry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you the driver of the vehicle?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any passengers in your vehicle?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of vehicle were you driving?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Nissan Altima.  A black Nissan Altima.  I think it was like a 2015.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where were you coming from at the time of the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I was coming from Lancaster City and I was headed down Columbia Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where were you headed to?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Home.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't you just tell me what happened in the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: So, I was on Columbia Avenue and there's a lot of traffic on that street, and I was stopped because of the traffic.  Then I just saw a car in my rearview mirror.  I stopped and I always just check back to see if anybody else is -- making sure everybody else is going to stop, and I just noticed this car, like, coming at a high rate of speed.  And at that point I was like, Wow, I hope this car slows down.  And boom, it didn't slow down.  And then I was rear ended.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just some followup questions on that.  So at the time of impact were you stopped?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you said you saw the vehicle prior to impact; correct?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you approximate how far the vehicle was when you first saw it?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: When I first saw it, it looked like it was probably about -- well, the part of that area that I was in, it could have been maybe about ten cars back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you able to approximate the speed of the vehicle?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: It was going faster than anything that I saw in my rearview mirror before.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you clarify that at all?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.  I couldn't tell you the speed, but I can tell you that it was alarming to see someone coming when I'm stopped and somebody not slowing down.  It was just...
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you say more than 15 miles an hour, 20 miles an hour?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.  It was probably around like at least 15, 20 miles an hour.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you said you saw the vehicle prior to impact.  Were you able to take any evasive measures to avoid the impact?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: When I looked out of my rearview mirror, I was, like, wow, this car is going to go, but the car that was in front of me didn't allow me to -- I wouldn't have been able to swerve.  So, I didn't get the opportunity to do anything.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What part of the other vehicle impacted your vehicle?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Her front end impacted my car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How would you categorize the severity of the impact?  Would you say it was a light impact, medium, heavy?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Well, I had to take my car to get it repaired.  The trunk, the fender, some under -- construction parts, I don't know what you call them, but that all had to get redone by the body shop.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How would you actually categorize the impact as you were in the vehicle?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Oh, my impact?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The impact, yes.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I would say it was heavy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: A heavy impact?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your airbags deploy?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So, upon impact, what happened to your body inside the vehicle?  Did you move forward, backward, to the left, to the right?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: So, upon impact, I felt two things:  I felt my abs get stressed out, and I guess that was because of the seatbelt catching me from the impact. And then the back of my head, because it felt -- I know for a fact that I blacked out for like a few seconds or whatever it was, because I was disoriented.  So, I didn't know if I hit my head on the steering wheel or the headset -- I mean, the headrest had hit the back of my head, or my head hit the headrest, whichever one you want to call it, but I felt that impact.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did your body move forward?  Is that what you are stating?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.  Well, the car hit me and it slammed my head into the headrest, which caused the stress of my stomach and then the back of my head.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So, your body moved backwards if you hit the headrest?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah, but it moved forward into the seatbelt.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It moved forward and backward, to summarize?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah, exactly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Once the seatbelt locked up?  Is that what you meant?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Right.  Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I think we have covered this a little bit, but just to specifically ask, did your body strike anything inside the vehicle?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.  Definitely the headrest.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else that you can recall?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Being pushed up against the seatbelt more.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you have any open cuts or bruises?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think you briefly mentioned this as well, but did you lose consciousness?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then after impact what happened?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: After impact, I -- Well, I looked back out the window to see -- I looked back out the rearview mirror to see if the car was there.  And then I didn't see a car behind me.  And then I exited my car.  I saw my car was hit, and I'm like, Wow. Like, What happened? And then I looked at the guy -- Well, I looked at the car that was behind me at that time. I said, Did you hit me?  And he was like, No, no. And I looked at this other car, and I said, Did you hit me?  And he's like, No. I said, Do you know who hit me?  And then he was like, Oh, it's the car up there. So the person that hit me had taken off. So, then I drove up in the middle of the median on Columbia Avenue to find the car with the front end damage.  And then finally I'm like, You hit me.  And she's like, Yeah. I said, You've got to pull over in this lot.  So then I pulled over in the lot, and she was like, Well, you know, I didn't think it was that bad, or something like that. I said, Hey, you've got to wait for the police to come.  And she's like, I have to go; I have to pick up my children.  How long is that going to take?  I said, Well, I don't know how long it's going to take, but we have to wait for the police. And I said, Your car is leaking.  And she said, Oh, my car is leaking?  Am I going to be able to get to work?  Is it okay to drive like this? I'm, like, Listen.  I don't know about your situation, but we have to wait for the police to come.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: And then she attempted to drive off and then I had to park her in so she couldn't pull out. It was a disaster.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just some followup questions on that. So the impact, you stated that you were stopped on Columbia Avenue, correct?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then you felt the impact and then she drove away?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you followed her on Columbia Avenue?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I had to catch up to her because it was a traffic jam on Columbia Avenue.  Well, not a traffic jam, but everybody was stopped. And then, again, once I was hit, she pulled over.  Like I pulled into the median just to try to let the traffic pass, and then other people were going onto the shoulder to go around me.  And then that's when the guy -- somebody was like, Hey, there's a car up there.  And I drove up, you know, beside the car actually to figure out who it was. And then I was able to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How were you able to get her attention?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I was like, Hey.  Because I looked at her car and I was like, Hey, you hit me, pull over.  And then that's when she pulled over.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So she had her window down and you were able --
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.  I was just signifying.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you were just making hand gestures for her to pull off the side of the road?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And she did so, obviously?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you said you pulled over into a parking lot?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think the police report might have said it was a --
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Dairy Queen.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- Dairy Queen parking lot.  Does that sound correct?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who called the police?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I called the police.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you mentioned that you had a conversation with her and that was basically about how she had to go and pick up her kids and her vehicle was drivable?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was anything else done?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Excuse me?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did she say anything else?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: She just said, I am going to be late to pick up my children; I can't be late.  And, I have to go, and, I can't wait here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think you stated that you parked her in so that she couldn't leave, correct?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So when the police arrived, she was still there?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you speak to the police?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Did I speak to the police?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you tell them the same thing you just told me?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did you leave the accident scene?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I left the accident scene in my vehicle.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So your vehicle was drivable at that point?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did the police ask you if you wanted an ambulance?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did you say?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I said no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why did you say no?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I said no because at the time I wanted to get home from the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So even though you said you lost consciousness, you still didn't want to get that checked out?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Not at the moment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then where did you go?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I went home.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then where was the next place that you sought treatment for injuries sustained in the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: So after I went home, I was like, wow, I'm feeling kind of foggy.  You know what, I never felt this way before, so I went to the emergency room.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you drove yourself to the emergency room?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I believe my wife drove me to the emergency room.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you approximately know how many hours you went to the emergency room after the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it the same day, though?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.  I think so, yeah. Or, no.  It was probably the day later. I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The same day or a day later?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At that point where were you feeling pain on your body?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: At that point that's when the pain intensified, and then I was feeling pain, again, in the abdomen area, lower back and the back of the head.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So on a zero-to-ten pain scale, with zero being absolutely no pain and ten being the most pain you ever felt, at that point after the accident, how would you categorize the pain in your abs?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: That was an eight.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how about your lower back?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: That was the same all around.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: An eight?  And your head was an eight as well then?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.  That was a nine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did the hospital say when you got there?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: They said they would check me out for -- they would check my abs, check my head, give me an MRI.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the results of the MRI?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I do not remember the results of the MRI.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember anything else they did?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And they discharged you, I'm guessing?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know how long you were at the hospital prior to discharge?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I was at the hospital for a few hours. Then they gave me some kind of pain medicine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That was my next question:  Upon discharge, did the hospital say anything or did they provide you any medication?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: They just told me that if I felt groggy or anything like that, you know, let them know.  If anything continues to get worse, stop back in, if anything gets worse.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think you mentioned medication.  Do you remember what kind of medication they gave you?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it an over-the-counter medication, a prescription medication, do you remember?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I think they gave me some Tylenol.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Tylenol?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where is the next place that you went for your injuries?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: The next place I went to was to a chiropractor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the chiropractor's name?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Sheehan Chiropractic.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So how did you come to find this chiropractor?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: So, when I went to the chiropractor, I -- Can you repeat the question?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did you find the chiropractor?  Did you look through the phonebook, did someone recommend you?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah, yeah, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Had you previously seen him?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No, no, no.  I had did some research, and then I was like, all right, I am going to go to this chiropractor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Like a Goggle search?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's probably what I would have done.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you went to the chiropractor, and when you went to him what did you complain of?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I told him that I was in a car accident. And then he said, Okay, let me run some tests and let me see where you are at.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember what kind of tests he ran?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: He did a spinal alignment test just to -- and then he did some kind of muscle testing to measure if different muscles are being stressed out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember the results of those tests?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: He said that I had damage or muscle intensity in my lower back and the back of my head and shoulders.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said in your lower back, back of your head and shoulders?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then what did he say?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: He said that having -- getting an alignment or getting some kind of treatments would help reduce that, reduce those stresses.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at this point when you went to see the chiropractor, we talked earlier about that pain scale and you had put your lower back at an eight. Had it intensified, lowered or stayed at that pain level?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: At that time it was the same.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how about your head?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: The same.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: A nine?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what about your abs at this point?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: It was the same.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did he say anything about that?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Actually, he was the one that said, hey.  I said, I don't know what's going on, but my abs hurt. And then he was like, Yeah, that can be from your seatbelt locking up from the impact.  And I was like, Oh, that makes sense because I never felt my abs be that tight before.  Or maybe it wasn't tight; it was just the seatbelt just catching me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any bruising there from the seatbelt?  Sometimes people do.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I don't recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said that the chiropractor recommended alignments; is that correct?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.  He recommended alignments, and he did some other tests.  And then he said, you know, Are you having trouble concentrating or something like that?  And I was like, Yeah, I feel like foggy. And then he was like, Well, it's possible that you suffered a concussion.  And I said, Well -- and then he asked me did I ever have any concussions before, and said I said no.  And he said, You have the symptoms of a concussion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: And I was like, Well, that makes sense because I wasn't feeling as sharp as I normally feel.  For the things that I do I am normally one hundred percent focused and I just could not get that focus back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What else did he say?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: He said, you know, You can start this treatment and these treatments will have a possibility of being able to get you back to the way that you used to be.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The treatments being the alignments?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: The treatments was -- Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did he recommend any treatment for the concussion?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Did he recommend any treatment for the concussion?  No.  He just said that, you know, getting an alignment would alleviate some -- it would alleviate some stress on the joints and it's probably muscles that are swelling up that are keeping me out of alignment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you have those alignments?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did they help you?

speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.  I do remember the nerve damage one because that was a really difficult test to take.

text: Holding, yeah.

text: Were you taking any medications prior to this accident?

text: No.

speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.

text: Yes.

text: Who said that?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Sheehan.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what specific injury did he say was caused by this accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: He said that it was possible that I had a concussion from the accident, which made me like black out.  So that's what -- I mean, I just call it a blackout.  He was like, It's a concussion; that's what probably happened to you. I said yeah, but...  He said, Did you hit your head?  And I was like, I didn't think I had actually hit my head because I didn't have any marks on my forehead, but I was just thinking of my forehead.  I didn't think that my headrest had slammed into the back of my head.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did he say that he thought that your lower back pain was caused by this accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.  So he ran tests at the beginning and then he ran tests at the end of my therapy with him. And there was a chart and it showed all the different stress areas.  And I believe it was pretty much the same, with just like some areas changed a little bit, but it wasn't -- it didn't like totally clear out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And he said this was caused by the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: He said that I definitely had a concussion. And I said, Well, I know I didn't feel unfocused before I came -- before the accident, and that's what his conclusion was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about your lower back pain, did he say that was caused by the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: He said that's the whole combination of a rear -- a rear-end accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And same thing with your head?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It was caused by the accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just to clarify, you mentioned something before when you said the back of your head, and I think then you mentioned your neck. Is your neck pain associated also with your head?  That's not something that --
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I mean, it's the back of my head, so it's not like the top part.  It's just like the lower part.  So, you know, at some point your head becomes your neck, so it's that whole section right there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So any time that you were mentioning you had pain in your head, you meant the pain in your neck/head area?  Is that correct to say?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yes.  The neck/head area, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just to summarize everything, when we were talking about the pain that you had experienced in your accident, you said you had pain in your abs, your lower back and your head, slash, neck. Did you feel any other pain that we haven't spoken about?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So just those three areas?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any injuries prior to this accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you been involved in any motor vehicle accident prior to this one?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have a note on March 10th, 2013.  So this would have been about three years prior to the accident that we are here for.  It says that you were at Lancaster Regional Medical Center Emergency Room complaining of lower back pain following a motor vehicle accident about 12 hours before this visit.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: When was that?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: March 10, 2013. It said a tractor trailer had pulled forward.  You were a passenger.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Oh, yes.  Yeah.  That was when my wife was driving.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were a passenger in the vehicle?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't you tell me about that?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: She -- Let me see.  Oh.  She was driving; I was on the passenger side.  We were off of an exit on Route 30 and a tractor trailer backed into the front of us.  Like he had pulled too far into the intersection and then he started to reverse, and we were, like, stuck in the middle.  And then he, like, ran into the front of the car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And were you injured in that accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I didn't seek any, like, extra therapy, but the insurance company recommended that I should go see somebody if I felt any more worse -- like if I felt any additional pain.  I went in and then I felt like I was -- I felt like I was okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think it mentions in the note that the emergency room recommended that you see your primary care physician in two to three days. Did you ever end up doing that?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I'm not sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So prior to the accident, did you have any back pain?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you had any accidents since this accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I want to talk about what you could do prior to this accident that you can no longer do; basically how this accident has affected your life.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: What's your question again?  Sorry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What could you do prior to this accident that you can no longer do because of the injuries sustained in this accident?  So, basically how this accident affected your life.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: So the way this accident has affected my life is that it's frustrating that I can't focus as well as I used to be able to focus.  I felt like a lot of things were more sharp.  I feel like where -- I even feel like sometimes my rate of speech used to be a lot faster and now it's slower.  I feel like I can't formulate my sentences regularly, like I can't get across what I'm thinking in my head.  It makes me like almost, like, I don't know.  It's just all jumbled up. So that, and then like if I tried to just go move some furniture around, I have to think twice.  And then if I go ahead and do it, then sometimes I can get a sharp pain and then I have to stop, you know, stop doing that and just wait or get some help.  But it's just a continuous situation that I have to think before I do everything that I do now.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Regarding when you said that it was frustrating with your rate of speech and stuff to that effect, have you ever thought about seeking out a doctor to get some tests done regarding your head to see why that's happening?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Well, I just thought that -- I just thought it was a new way of life.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there anything that you can't do now because of this accident?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: That I can't do?  I just can't move like I used to be able to move.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But nothing specific?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: I haven't tried to test myself to a higher degree to see where my actual limitations are.  I can just visually look and say, Oh, this dresser, or this desk, or this TV, like I may not want to do that because I know that it's going to -- it's almost like if I move heavier objects, something around like 40 pounds, 50 pounds, that I feel like my back, like, collapses and pinches on a nerve and just shoots a straight pain to my head. And it's just like, Put that down.  And it's like, Okay, let me put it down.  And then sometimes I can pick it up and then I'm just, like, careful, like, trying to keep myself, my posture straight so that I don't pinch anything.  I just try to move straight without flexing or turning to the left or to the right too much to cause like -- to get an inflammation or something like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have to move heavy things often?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No, just when they need to be moved, so... I'm not a mover.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just stuff around the house?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah.  Just stuff around the house.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And outside of having to move stuff around the house, does anything else you do cause this pain?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Like sometimes when I'm -- even if I'm mopping or something like that, and I try and, like, twist to mop, you know, something simple like that can just trigger it also.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else?  I'm just trying to get a list of all the triggers that would cause the pain.
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: Yeah, yeah.  Triggers are like moving objects.  Triggers are like walking for like a real extended period of time. Yeah, just, you know, like walking sometimes just makes my back hurt after a while. Moving objects, walking.  What else? Going up the steps is critical, because I -- especially when you're trying to go up the steps and you're standing there, like, stretch your leg out, stretch your back out, and then I go up the steps. It's just more I try to take the elevator.  I'm always looking for the elevator versus the steps where I used to be able to take the steps without a problem, where I used to enjoy taking the steps.  Now it's like, Do you want to really do that?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else?
speaker: MS. EAGER

text: No.
